documents.name: documents
documents.description: Parsed content from uploaded files, processed via OCR and other techniques; ready for use (e.g., LLM input).

raw_files.name: raw_files
raw_files.description: Raw uploaded files with filename titles and full content, without processing or chunking. Simple format: just title and content for each file.

file_urls.name: file_urls
file_urls.description: References the uploaded files' paths, enabling further use, like email attachments or code interpreter with CSVs.

data.text:
Here is the information regarding White Blood Cell (WBC) and Hemoglobin levels based on the provided lab guide:

**White Blood Cell Count (WBC)**
*   **What it means:** WBCs are your body's infection-fighting cells. They help identify and fight inflammation and infection[^93826.1.0].
*   **Normal Range:** 5,000 – 10,000 cells per mm³ (or 5.0–10.0 x 10⁹/L)[^93826.1.0].
*   **Minimum Normal Count:** The lower limit of the normal range is **5,000 cells per mm³**[^93826.1.0].
*   **Abnormal Values:** High levels often indicate infection, inflammation, or steroid use. Detailed low values are less common but can occur[^93826.1.0].

**Hemoglobin (HGB)**
*   **What it means:** This is the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen throughout your body[^93826.1.0].
*   **Normal Range (Adults):** 14 – 17.4 g/dL[^93826.1.0].
*   **Normal Range (Children):** 9.5 – 20.5 g/dL[^93826.1.0].
*   **Abnormal Values:** Low levels typically indicate anemia[^93826.1.0].

Would you like me to also create a sample template of how such an agent should present a CBC report step by step?

citations.title: Common_Labs.pdf
citations.text:
# COMMON LABS AND WHAT THEY MEAN



The following are labs that are commonly drawn in neuromuscular centers. Normal ranges have been provided by mayocliniclabs.com. Common reasons for obtaining these labs, as well as possible reasons for high and low values, are included. This list is not exhaustive and any abnormal values, questions, or concerns should be discussed with your neuromuscular center.



# Blood Test



# Normal Range



About / Common Reasons (not ALL reasons) to be Outside of Normal Range



# Complete Blood Count (CBC)



CBC includes components of white blood cells (infection fighting cells), red blood cells (oxygen-carrying cells), and measurements of how effectively the blood is able to clot or respond to real or perceived infection.



# White Blood Cell Count (WBC)



5,000-10,000 WBCs per mm3 or 5.0-10.0 x 109 WBC per Liter



– High: Infection, inflammation; may be



elevated with steroid use – Low: Not commonly low



# Red Blood Cell Count (RBC)



# – Children: 3.8–6.0 million RBCs per



mcL or 3.8–6.0 x 1012/L



# – High: Dehydration – Low: Anemia



# – Adults: 4.5–5.5 million RBCs per



# microliter (mcL) or 4.5–5.5 x 1012/ liter (L)



# Hemoglobin (HGB)



– Children: 9.5–20.5 g/dL or 95–205



# g/L



# – Low: Anemia



# – Adults: 14–17.4 grams per



# deciliter (g/dL) or 140–174 grams per liter (g/L)



# Hematocrit (HCT) – Children: 29%–59% or 0.29–0.59



# – Low: Anemia



# volume fraction



– Adults: 42%–52% or 0.42–0.52



# volume fraction



# Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)



– 6 months-23 months: 69.5-81.7 fL – 24 months-35 months: 71.3-84.0



# fL



– 3-5 years: 77.2-89.5 fL – 6-11 years: 77.8-91.1 fL – 12-14 years: 79.9-93.0 fL – 15-17 years: 82.5-98.0 fL – Adults: 78.2-97.9 fL



Measures the size of the average red blood cell. – Low: Microcytic anemia – High: Macrocytic anemia



# Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH)



27-33 pg



Measures the average amount of hemoglobin in a single red blood cell. – Low: Iron deficiency anemia – High: Can indicate macrocytic anemia



# Notes



1

# COMMON LABS AND WHAT THEY MEAN



The following are labs that are commonly drawn in neuromuscular centers. Normal ranges have been provided by mayocliniclabs.com. Common reasons for obtaining these labs, as well as possible reasons for high and low values, are included. This list is not exhaustive and any abnormal values, questions, or concerns should be discussed with your neuromuscular center.



# Blood Test



# Normal Range



About / Common Reasons (not ALL reasons) to be Outside of Normal Range



# Complete Blood Count (CBC)



CBC includes components of white blood cells (infection fighting cells), red blood cells (oxygen-carrying cells), and measurements of how effectively the blood is able to clot or respond to real or perceived infection.



# White Blood Cell Count (WBC)



5,000-10,000 WBCs per mm3 or 5.0-10.0 x 109 WBC per Liter



– High: Infection, inflammation; may be



elevated with steroid use – Low: Not commonly low



# Red Blood Cell Count (RBC)



# – Children: 3.8–6.0 million RBCs per



mcL or 3.8–6.0 x 1012/L



# – High: Dehydration – Low: Anemia



# – Adults: 4.5–5.5 million RBCs per



# microliter (mcL) or 4.5–5.5 x 1012/ liter (L)



# Hemoglobin (HGB)



– Children: 9.5–20.5 g/dL or 95–205



# g/L



# – Low: Anemia



# – Adults: 14–17.4 grams per



# deciliter (g/dL) or 140–174 grams per liter (g/L)



# Hematocrit (HCT) – Children: 29%–59% or 0.29–0.59



# – Low: Anemia



# volume fraction



– Adults: 42%–52% or 0.42–0.52



# volume fraction



# Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)



– 6 months-23 months: 69.5-81.7 fL – 24 months-35 months: 71.3-84.0



# fL



– 3-5 years: 77.2-89.5 fL – 6-11 years: 77.8-91.1 fL – 12-14 years: 79.9-93.0 fL – 15-17 years: 82.5-98.0 fL – Adults: 78.2-97.9 fL



Measures the size of the average red blood cell. – Low: Microcytic anemia – High: Macrocytic anemia



# Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH)



27-33 pg



Measures the average amount of hemoglobin in a single red blood cell. – Low: Iron deficiency anemia – High: Can indicate macrocytic anemia



# Notes



1

data.name: Google

citation_list.name: citation_list
citation_list.description: List of citation objects referenced in the completion.

subflow_tool_input.name: subflow_tool_input
subflow_tool_input.description: The input string passed by the LLM when calling a subflow tool.

citations.name: citation_list
citations.description: List of citation objects referenced in the completion.

data.system:
You will get the blood test report as context along with the user’s question.

Explain the report in short, clear bullet points.

Point out which values are normal, high, or low.

Keep the tone friendly and easy to understand.

Be brief but helpful, so the user quickly understands their results.


Would you like me to also create a sample template of how such an agent should present a CBC report step by step?
data.formatted_prompt:
system:
You will get the blood test report as context along with the user’s question.

Explain the report in short, clear bullet points.

Point out which values are normal, high, or low.

Keep the tone friendly and easy to understand.

Be brief but helpful, so the user quickly understands their results.

Would you like me to also create a sample template of how such an agent should present a CBC report step by step?

Cite sources using [^#.#.#] at the end of sentences when needed, for example: 'Ice is less dense than water[^1234.1.1].' NO SPACE between the last word and the citation. Cite the most relevant sources that answer the question. Avoid citing irrelevant sources. DO NOT invent citations—only use citation indexes that are provided in the format [^#.#.#].

Tool call responses may also contain citable information identified by the following format [^\d+.\d+.\d+]. Cite this information if you have used it.

No documents provided.

3.5 – 5.0 g/dL



3.5-5.0 – Over 7 years: 7-15



– 3 years: 18-26 mmol/L – 4-5 years: 19-27 mmol/L – 6-7 years: 20-28 mmol/L – 8-17 years: 21-29 mmol/L – > or =18 years: 22-29 mmol/L



– 1-17 years: 9.3-10.6 mg/dL – 18-59 years: 8.6-10.0 mg/dL



About / Common Reasons (not ALL reasons) to be Outside of Normal Range



Help activate allergic responses. – High: Generally indicate an allergic reaction, infection (parasitic or otherwise), inflammation



Help wound healing, infection and allergic reactions. – High: Can indicate a blood disorder – Low: Allergic reactions, infections



Circulate in the blood to pick up signs of danger. – High: May indicate a chronic infection, autoimmune diseases or blood disorder – Low: Usually with an overall low white blood cell count or exposure to toxins



Evaluates the health and function of the kidneys.



Protein filtered by the kidneys. – High: May indicate dehydration – Low: Usually occurs with edema



Checks the level of acid in your blood. – High: May indicate acidosis



Alteration of bicarbonate and carbon dioxide may reflect an acid-base imbalance. Bicarbonate levels are evaluated with carbon dioxide and other electrolytes to screen for electrolyte imbalances.



Helps to screen for bone, kidney, parathyroid and gastrointestinal health/function. – High: Movement of calcium from



the bones to the blood; severely high calcium can cause heart arrhythmias – Low: Poorly functioning parathyroid



glands or a lack of vitamin D synthesis of the body; may indicate kidney failure



# Notes

– High: May indicate chronic iron overload

# dehydration, low blood volume



# – Low: Uncommon

– Low: May indicate over-hydration,

Indication of fluid/electrolyte balance in the body. – High: Can be dangerous and should be



monitored closely



– Low: Common with vomiting, diarrhea,



# iron deficiency

# body fluid

Screens for kidney function. – High: Kidney issues or causes that may



lead to kidney issues



– Low: Uncommon but may indicate



# severe starvation, severe liver disease

# dL

– Desirable: <200 mg/dL – Borderline high: 200-239 mg/dL – High: > or =240 mg/dL Adults: <200 mg/dL



# High-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol (HDL)



Children: – Low HDL: <40 mg/dL – Borderline low: 40-45 mg/dL – Acceptable: >45 mg/dL Adults: 40 mg/dL



About / Common Reasons (not ALL reasons) to be Outside of Normal Range



Results are generally evaluated as a set to evaluate liver function.



– High: Normal in Duchenne; indicates skeletal muscle breakdown, not liver dysfunction



Evaluation of liver, bone, intestinal and parathyroid diseases. – High: Issues with liver or bone; may be elevated right after accelerated bone growth



– High: Normal in Duchenne; indicates skeletal muscle breakdown, not liver dysfunction



Screen for nutritional status. – High: May be high if dehydrated – Low: May indicate liver disease,



poor protein intake, tissue damage, inflammation



# Screen for overall health.



Screen for liver function. – Abnormal: Jaundice (newborns) – High after Newborn: Breakdown of



# blood cells



# – Low: Liver obstruction or hepatitis



Measured to assess cardiovascular risk



Screens for risk of coronary heart disease. – High: Higher risk



Higher levels decrease the risk of coronary heart disease. – Normal: Decreased risk – Low: Higher risk of coronary artery



# disease

5","citation_id":"[^81724.5.0]","score":0.3420156240463257,"doc_name":"Common_Labs.pdf"},{"text":"# Blood Test



# Endocrine Labs



# 25 Hydroxyvitamin D (25 OH Vit D)



# Total Coenzyme Q 10 (CoQ10) Profile



# Parathyroid Hormone (PTH)



# Insulin (Free and Total)



# Glucose (Random, Non- Fasting)



# Creatine Kinase (CK)



# Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase Test (GGT)



# Hemoglobin A1C (HgbA1C)



# Normal Range



– <16 years: 24-86 pg/mL – > or =16 years: 18-64 pg/mL



– <18 years: 320-1,558 mcg/L – > or =18 years: 433-1,532 mcg/L



– 4 weeks-11 months: 8.0-61 pg/mL – 12 months-10 years: 11-59 pg/mL – 11 years-17 years: 15-68 pg/mL – 18 years and older: 15-65 pg/mL



# – Free Insulin: 2.6-24.9 mcIU/mL – Total Insulin: 2.6-24.9 mcIU/mL



– 0-11 months: not established – > or =1 year: 70-140 mg/dL



– < or =3 months: not established – >3 months: 39-308 U/L



– 0-11 months: <178 U/L – 12 months-6 years: <21 U/L – 7-12 years: <24 U/L – 13-17 years: <43 U/L – > or =18 years: 8-61 U/L



Over 18: – 4.0 – 5.6% normal – 5.7 - 6.4% Pre-diabetic; increased



risk for Diabetes – >6.5% - diabetes



About / Common Reasons (not ALL reasons) to be Outside of Normal Range



# – Low: A lack of vitamin D stores in the



# body



CoQ10 is essential for mitochondrial activity. A low value may reflect a need for supplemental CoQ10.



Serum calcium levels stimulate PTH release. The values are interpreted with calcium and phosphorous levels. A high level usually reflects a vitamin D deficiency.



Insulin regulates the utilization of glucose by the body. High insulin may indicate early type II diabetes (insulin resistance); low levels indicate type I (insulin dependent) diabetes.



A random glucose >200 mg/dL may indicate the presence of diabetes.



CK will always be elevated in Duchenne, reflecting skeletal muscle injury.



– High: May indicate liver disease;



often interpreted with the alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level. Normal GGT with high ALP is consistent with skeletal disease.



Result indicates potential risk for the development of pre-diabetes/diabetes.



# Notes

citation_list.title: Common_Labs.pdf
citation_list.text:
# COMMON LABS AND WHAT THEY MEAN



The following are labs that are commonly drawn in neuromuscular centers. Normal ranges have been provided by mayocliniclabs.com. Common reasons for obtaining these labs, as well as possible reasons for high and low values, are included. This list is not exhaustive and any abnormal values, questions, or concerns should be discussed with your neuromuscular center.



# Blood Test



# Normal Range



About / Common Reasons (not ALL reasons) to be Outside of Normal Range



# Complete Blood Count (CBC)



CBC includes components of white blood cells (infection fighting cells), red blood cells (oxygen-carrying cells), and measurements of how effectively the blood is able to clot or respond to real or perceived infection.



# White Blood Cell Count (WBC)



5,000-10,000 WBCs per mm3 or 5.0-10.0 x 109 WBC per Liter



– High: Infection, inflammation; may be



elevated with steroid use – Low: Not commonly low



# Red Blood Cell Count (RBC)



# – Children: 3.8–6.0 million RBCs per



mcL or 3.8–6.0 x 1012/L



# – High: Dehydration – Low: Anemia



# – Adults: 4.5–5.5 million RBCs per



# microliter (mcL) or 4.5–5.5 x 1012/ liter (L)



# Hemoglobin (HGB)



– Children: 9.5–20.5 g/dL or 95–205



# g/L



# – Low: Anemia



# – Adults: 14–17.4 grams per



# deciliter (g/dL) or 140–174 grams per liter (g/L)



# Hematocrit (HCT) – Children: 29%–59% or 0.29–0.59



# – Low: Anemia



# volume fraction



– Adults: 42%–52% or 0.42–0.52



# volume fraction



# Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)



– 6 months-23 months: 69.5-81.7 fL – 24 months-35 months: 71.3-84.0



# fL



– 3-5 years: 77.2-89.5 fL – 6-11 years: 77.8-91.1 fL – 12-14 years: 79.9-93.0 fL – 15-17 years: 82.5-98.0 fL – Adults: 78.2-97.9 fL



Measures the size of the average red blood cell. – Low: Microcytic anemia – High: Macrocytic anemia



# Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH)



27-33 pg



Measures the average amount of hemoglobin in a single red blood cell. – Low: Iron deficiency anemia – High: Can indicate macrocytic anemia



# Notes



1

– 3-5 years: 77.2-89.5 fL – 6-11 years: 77.8-91.1 fL – 12-14 years: 79.9-93.0 fL – 15-17 years: 82.5-98.0 fL – Adults: 78.2-97.9 fL



Measures the size of the average red blood cell. – Low: Microcytic anemia – High: Macrocytic anemia



# Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH)



27-33 pg



Measures the average amount of hemoglobin in a single red blood cell. – Low: Iron deficiency anemia – High: Can indicate macrocytic anemia



# Notes



1

citation_list.title: Common_Labs.pdf
citation_list.text:
# COMMON LABS AND WHAT THEY MEAN



The following are labs that are commonly drawn in neuromuscular centers. Normal ranges have been provided by mayocliniclabs.com. Common reasons for obtaining these labs, as well as possible reasons for high and low values, are included. This list is not exhaustive and any abnormal values, questions, or concerns should be discussed with your neuromuscular center.



# Blood Test



# Normal Range



About / Common Reasons (not ALL reasons) to be Outside of Normal Range



# Complete Blood Count (CBC)



CBC includes components of white blood cells (infection fighting cells), red blood cells (oxygen-carrying cells), and measurements of how effectively the blood is able to clot or respond to real or perceived infection.



# White Blood Cell Count (WBC)



5,000-10,000 WBCs per mm3 or 5.0-10.0 x 109 WBC per Liter



– High: Infection, inflammation; may be



elevated with steroid use – Low: Not commonly low



# Red Blood Cell Count (RBC)



# – Children: 3.8–6.0 million RBCs per



mcL or 3.8–6.0 x 1012/L



# – High: Dehydration – Low: Anemia



# – Adults: 4.5–5.5 million RBCs per



# microliter (mcL) or 4.5–5.5 x 1012/ liter (L)



# Hemoglobin (HGB)



– Children: 9.5–20.5 g/dL or 95–205



# g/L



# – Low: Anemia



# – Adults: 14–17.4 grams per



# deciliter (g/dL) or 140–174 grams per liter (g/L)



# Hematocrit (HCT) – Children: 29%–59% or 0.29–0.59



# – Low: Anemia



# volume fraction



– Adults: 42%–52% or 0.42–0.52



# volume fraction



# Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)



– 6 months-23 months: 69.5-81.7 fL – 24 months-35 months: 71.3-84.0



# fL



– 3-5 years: 77.2-89.5 fL – 6-11 years: 77.8-91.1 fL – 12-14 years: 79.9-93.0 fL – 15-17 years: 82.5-98.0 fL – Adults: 78.2-97.9 fL



Measures the size of the average red blood cell. – Low: Microcytic anemia – High: Macrocytic anemia



# Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH)



27-33 pg



Measures the average amount of hemoglobin in a single red blood cell. – Low: Iron deficiency anemia – High: Can indicate macrocytic anemia



# Notes



1
